revision.comment: Rescuing 4 sources and tagging 0 as dead.) #IABot (v2.0
revision.text:
{{short description| Competitive watersport using swimfins for propulsion }} {{About|the underwater sport|the sport of swimming|Swimming (sport)}} {{Infobox sport |name = Finswimming |image = Jarolím RP.jpg |imagesize = 200px |caption = Finswimming with monofin |union = [[Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|CMAS]] |nickname = |first = |country/region = International |registered = |clubs = |contact = no |team = |mgender = Yes, but usually in separate events |category = Aquatic, indoor, outdoor | equipment = [[diving mask]], [[Snorkeling#The snorkel|snorkel]], [[swimfins|fins]], [[Scuba set|open circuit scuba set]] | venue = [[swimming pool]], [[open-water diving|open water]] | obsolete = | olympic = No | paralympic = | IWGA = [[1981 World Games|1981]]{{snds}}present }} '''Finswimming''' is an [[underwater sports|underwater sport]] consisting of four techniques involving [[Human swimming|swimming]] with the use of [[swimfins|fins]] either on the water's surface using a snorkel with either [[monofins]] or bifins or [[underwater]] with monofin either by holding one's breath or using [[Scuba set#Types#Open circuit|open circuit]] [[scuba diving]] equipment. Events exist over distances similar to [[Swimming (sport)|swimming competitions]] for both [[swimming pool]] and [[open-water diving|open water]] venues. Competition at world and continental level is organised by the [[Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques]] (CMAS). The sport's first world championship was held in 1976. It also has been featured at the [[World Games]] as a trend sport since 1981 and was demonstrated at the [[2015 European Games]] in June 2015. ==Rules and description of the sport== ===Competitors=== Competitors are described within the International Rules as 'swimmers' rather than as finswimmers or [[underwater diving|divers]].{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|pages=2–3|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} ===Classes of competition=== Competition is divided in two classes: swimming pool and long distance (also called open water).{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|pages=10–14|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} A swimming pool must be 50 m long by 21 m wide and 1.8 m deep, i.e. an [[Olympic-size swimming pool]] (also known as a long course pool) suitable for the holding of swimming races for either the [[Olympic Games]] and a [[FINA]] world championships.{{cite web | title = Facilities Rules: FR 3 Swimming Pools for Olympic Games and World Championships | url = http://www.fina.org/content/fr-3-swimming-pools-olympic-games-and-world-championships| publisher = [[FINA]] | accessdate = 2018-01-30 }} The International Rules do not permit the use of 25m length pools (known as [[short course]]) although these are used in regional and national competition.{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|pages=21–22|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} Long distance sites include both the sea and natural water bodies such as freshwater rivers and lakes. Site selection criteria include 'low current and tides' and water quality 'appropriate for swimming' as certified by a local authority. The site, when in use for competition, will be marked by buoys, patrolled by safety [[boat]]s and will have observation points (or additional boats) for judges to oversee any turns present in the course. ===Techniques=== [[File:SpecialFins.jpg|right|thumb|Monofin & Bi-fins]] ====Surface finswimming==== Surface finswimming (also known by its acronym, '''SF''') is swimming on the surface of the water using mask, snorkel, and monofins. SF races are held for distances of 50, 100, 200, 400, 800, 1500, 4 × 100 relays and 4 × 200 relays (meters) in swimming pools and over various long distances in the open water environment. Swimmers must remain on the surface of the water at all times for the duration of the race except when starting or make a turns at the end of a swimming pool where an immersion over a distance of 15m is permitted. ====Apnoea finswimming==== Apnoea finswimming (also known by its acronym, '''AP''', and as '''apnoea''' or '''apnea''') is underwater swimming in a swimming pool using a mask, monofin and holding one's breath. AP races are held for the distance of 50m. A swimmer's face must be immersed for the duration of the race otherwise he/she risks disqualification. AP races are not conducted in open water for 'safety and security reasons'. ====Immersion finswimming with breathing apparatus==== Immersion finswimming with breathing apparatus (also known by its acronym, '''IM''', and as '''immersion''') is underwater swimming using mask, monofin and underwater breathing apparatus conducted in a swimming pool. While there are no requirements on how a breathing apparatus is carried, it cannot be exchanged or abandoned during a race. IM races are held for distances of 100 and 400 m. A swimmer's face must be immersed for the duration of the race or risk disqualification. IM races are not conducted in open water for 'safety and security reasons'. Historically, IM swims were conducted in open water up to distances of 1000m.{{cite web|title=A book about History of UW orienteering|url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=260186227361650&set=a.260185977361675.60169.255752577805015&type=3&theater|publisher=CMAS|accessdate=19 January 2014|page=4}} ====Bi-fins==== Bi-fins (also known by its acronym, '''BF''' or as ''''stereo-fins'''') is swimming on the surface of the water with mask, snorkel and a pair of fins using a crawl style. BF races are held for distances of 50, 100 and 200m in swimming pools and over various long distances in the open water environment such as 4km and 6km. It is reported that BF was introduced in 2006 to provide the opportunity for competition by swimmers who cannot afford to purchase a set of monofins. Swimmers must remain on the surface of the water at all times for the duration of the race except when starting or make a turns at the end of a swimming pool where an immersion of a distance of 15m is permitted.{{cite web|title=Finswimming|url=http://www.luigiferraro.it/en/finswimming|publisher=Official site dedicated to Luigi Ferraro|accessdate=3 December 2013}} ===Equipment=== [[file:skorjenkoflosse.jpg|thumb|Monofin]] [[File:Tuba-nap.jpg|right|thumb|Finswimming snorkel]] Finswimming which is often compared to [[Swimming (sport)|sports swimming]]{{cite web|title=Strange Sports: There's something fishy down Tuggeranong way...|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article133919981|publisher=The Canberra Times|accessdate=19 January 2014|pages=36|date=15 December 1995}} differs from that sport in the use of [[diving mask|masks]], fins, snorkels and underwater breathing apparatus. This reflects the sport’s origins in the [[underwater diving]] techniques of [[snorkelling]], [[freediving|breath-hold diving]] and [[scuba diving|open circuit scuba diving]]. Apart from requiring the use of a mask for protection of the eyes and for the ability to see underwater, the international rules have no requirements regarding selection. Centre-mounted snorkels (also known as front snorkels) are the only type approved for use subject to meeting minimum and maximum requirements in tube length and internal diameter. Fins are also regulated by international rules. Monofins have a maximum size which can be checked by the use of a template while bi-fins must be one of the brands certified (i.e. [[Homologation|homologated]]) by CMAS.{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|pages=3–6|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} Underwater breathing apparatus is restricted to open circuit scuba using compressed atmospheric [[air]] as the breathing gas. The use of [[Nitrox|oxygen enriched mixtures]] is forbidden. [[Diving cylinder|Cylinders]] are limited by maximum [[Diving cylinder#cylinder pressure rating|cylinder pressure rating]] of 200 bar and a minimum [[Diving cylinder#cylinder capacity|cylinder capacity]] of 0.4 litres. While there are no requirements for [[diving regulator|regulator]]s, swimmers appear to be free to modify these to remove any unnecessary parts. Garments such as [[Competitive swimwear|swimsuits]], [[swim cap]]s and [[Diving suit|wetsuits]], and the use of logos printed on these garments and the equipment is also subject to the requirements of the international rules. === Age groupings and associated restrictions === The following age groupings and associated restrictions for both men and women are mandated by the International Rules.{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|page=2|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="cccccc" | Age group title | Age group code | Age range | Restrictions |- | Senior | A | 18 years & over | No restrictions |- | Junior | B | 16–17 years | No restrictions |- | Junior | C | 14–15 years | Maximum openwater swim of 8km |- | Junior | D | 12–13 years | Maximum openwater swim of 6km
Maximum AP distance of 25m |- | Junior | E | less than 11 years | Known as the 'pre-competition group'; national rules apply for this age group as there is no international competition for this group. |- | Master | V0 | 25–34 years | No restrictions |- | Master | V1 | 35–44 years | No restrictions |- | Master | V2 | 45–54 years | No restrictions |- |} ==Origins and history== The sport developed in Europe following the ready availability of the first rubber fins during the 1930s.{{cite web|title=Louis Marie de Corlieu|url=http://www.scubahalloffame.com/hallmembers/Early%20Pioneers/Corlieu.html|publisher=International Scuba Diving Hall of Fame|accessdate=13 January 2014}} Luigi Ferraro, Italian diving pioneer, is reported as organising the first fin-swimming competition in the sea during 1951 followed by a {{convert|100|km|abbr=off}} ocean swim in 1955. The first competition in the [[Soviet Union]] was held during 1958.{{cite web|title=History of Underwater Sports: Finswimming|url=http://history.cmas.org/finswimming|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|accessdate=3 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161215163844/http://history.cmas.org/finswimming|archive-date=15 December 2016|url-status=dead}} The first European Championship which was a [[multi sport event]] involving both finswimming and [[underwater orienteering]] was held under the title of the First European Championship of Subaquatics Technical at [[Angera]], [[Italy]] in August 1967. The specific finswimming events were races over the distances of 40m and 1000m which are reported as using either surface swimming techniques or respectively apnoea and immersion techniques. In 1969, the first European Finswimming Championship to be separate of underwater orienteering was held in [[Locarno]], [[Switzerland]].{{cite web|title=1st European Championship|url=http://www.cmas.org/finswimming/114-28099.php|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|accessdate=3 December 2013}} The first World Championships were held in [[Hanover]], [[Germany]] during 1976 followed by the inclusion of the sport in the inaugural [[World Games]] in [[Santa Clara, California]], USA during 1981. In 1988, the first World Long Distance Championship was held in [[Paris]], [[France]] followed in 1989 by the first World Junior Championship in [[Dunaújváros]], [[Hungary]].{{cite web|title=1st World Championship|url=http://www.cmas.org/finswimming/114-28113.php|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|accessdate=12 August 2013}}{{cite web|title=Underwater Sports: Fin Swimming|url=http://www.theworldgames.org/the-sports/sports/trend-sports/underwater-sports-fin-swimming|publisher=the International World Games Association|accessdate=18 August 2013|pages=|date= }} The arrival of the monofin in the early 1970s lead to the breaking of all world records by the end of the decade due to the improved performance possible when used in lieu of bi-fins. In 2007, the first Bi Fin races using CMAS homologated fins were held. ==Sporting appeal and training== {{multiple issues|section=yes| {{ original research |section |date=January 2014}} {{refimprove section| date=January 2014}} }} ===Appeal=== The main appeal of finswimming is reported by some as being the speed that a swimmer can reach. The world record for the men's 50 m freestyle (long course) in sports swimming (see [[List of world records in swimming|World records in swimming]]), is 20.91 seconds (by [[César Cielo]] of [[Brazil]]). In finswimming it is 13.85 seconds (for 50 m apnoea by Pavel Kabanov of [[Russia]]) (see [[List of world records in finswimming|World records in finswimming]]). This is a 50% increase in speed over sports swimming. One of the great appeals of finswimming is that finswimmers do not need to be good sports swimmers.{{citation needed|date= January 2014}} Indeed, there is some evidence that top flight sports swimmers may make poorer finswimmers than well-trained finswimmers (see below).{{citation needed|date= January 2014}} ===Training=== Unlike most sports swimming training programmes, finswimming training tends to be far more specific and more like systems used for track running in [[sport of athletics|athletics]].{{citation needed|date= January 2014}} In addition, finswimming training tends to have more dry-side work, including a huge amount of [[core stability]] (as core strength), [[plyometrics]] and [[weight training]].{{citation needed|date= August 2014}} It has been recorded that sports swimmers tend to approach finswimming with preconceptions on technique, which can limit their success.Koulianou, M. & S. Vosniadou (2002). Differences between experts and novices in finswimming: A cognitive system analysis. Res-Systemica, 2, Special Issue: Proceedings of the fifth European Systems Science Congress, October 2002, Crete.Koulianou, M. & S. Vosniadou (2003). Differences between experts and novices in finswimming: A cognitive analysis of sports behavior. 2003 Cognitive Science Society European Proceedings.Koulianou, M. & S. Vosniadou (2006). Effects of Incompatible Prior Knowledge in Butterfly Style on Understanding Finswimming Style. Cognitive Science Journal, 30: 2539. ==Governing body== The governing body is the CMAS Finswimming Commission.{{cite web|title=About finswimming|url=http://www.cmas.org/finswimming/about-2012032622|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|accessdate=9 September 2013}} Its role includes the upgrading of the rules of competition when required, keeping of records for CMAS championships, the World Games and these of national federations where these match or exceed records achieved at international level, and the maintenance of the CMAS World Ranking which is a listing of the best performing senior and junior men and women from both the most recent [[Finswimming World Championships]] and the rounds of the World Cup. It also assists the CMAS Board of Directors and others organising competitions organised under the auspices of CMAS.{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1st 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|page=10 & 21–22|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} As of June 2015, national federations in the following countries and territories have affiliated with the Commission: [[Algeria]], [[Argentina]], [[Armenia]], [[Austria]], [[Australia]], [[Belgium]], [[Belarus]], [[Canada]], [[Cameroon]], [[Cape Verde]], [[Chile]], [[Colombia]], [[Cuba]], [[China]], [[Croatia]], [[Cyprus]], [[Czech Republic]], [[Denmark]], [[Ecuador]], [[Egypt]], [[Estonia]], [[Finland]], [[France]], [[Germany]], [[United Kingdom|Great Britain]], [[Greece]], [[Hungary]], [[Hong Kong]], [[Indonesia]], [[Italy]], [[Japan]], [[Jordan]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Kenya]], [[Korea]], [[Kuwait]], [[Kyrgyz Republic]], [[Lebanon]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Libya]], [[Mexico]], [[Marianas]], [[Montenegro]], [[Netherlands]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[Peru]], [[Philippines]], [[San Marino]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Serbia]], [[Singapore]], [[Slovakia]], [[Slovenia]], [[Spain]], [[Switzerland]], [[Syria]], [[Russia]], [[Tunisia]], [[Turkey]], [[Taiwan]], [[Thailand]], [[United Arab Emirates]], [[United States of America]], [[Venezuela]] and [[Vietnam]].{{cite web|title=Federations (finswimming)|url= http://www.cmas.org/cmas/federations?continent=&comme=0&commi=4 |publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|accessdate=17 June 2015}} == Competition at international level == ===CMAS competitions=== As of 2007, CMAS directly oversees the following four competitions at international level: the World Championship, Continental Championships, the World Cup and the CMAS Junior Trophy.{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|page=8|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} ====World Championship==== {{further|Finswimming World Championships}} The World Championship is held every two years in odd-numbered years for senior swimmers starting with the year 2007 and in even-numbered years for junior swimmers starting with the year 2008. Pool competition held over five days while open water competition is held over a maximum of three days.{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|pages=7–9|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} ====World Cup==== This is an annual event which was first held in 2006 and consists of a minimum of three rounds including a final all known as meetings which are attended by swimmers from clubs affiliated to a CMAS national federation. Races are held in both swimming pool and open water sites for individuals and clubs in the age groupings of senior and junior for both male and female.{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|page=9|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} ====CMAS Junior Trophy==== This is an annual swimming pool-based event for junior national teams for both male and female swimmers.{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|page=9&10|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} ====Continental championships==== Continental championships which are conducted in an identical manner to the world championships require a minimum of five countries from a continental body such as [[Africa]], [[Americas|America]], [[Asia]], [[Europe]] and [[Oceania]] as defined by the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC). The Continental championships are held every two years in odd-numbered years for senior swimmers starting with the year 2008 and in even-numbered years for junior swimmers starting with the year 2007.{{cite web|title=National Olympic Committees|url=http://www.olympic.org/ioc-governance-national-olympic-committees|publisher=International Olympic Committee|accessdate=11 December 2013}} The European Championships have run since 1967 and have been held 21 times.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} Asian Finswimming Championships is reported to have been held 13 times with the first being held in 1989 and the most being held during 2012 in [[Da Nang]], [[Vietnam]].{{cite web|title=Results for the 13th Asian Finswimming Championships and the 1st Asian Juniors Finswimming Competition|url=http://www.cmasasia.org//history/word/13th_Asian_Finswimming_Championships_results.pdf|publisher=Asian Underwater Federation|accessdate=24 October 2013}} ===Other CMAS-aligned events=== There have been three Pan-American Championships, starting in 1993, with the last being held in 2001 in [[Cali, Colombia]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} There have also been five "Arab Zone" Championships, the last was held in 2003 (in [[Beirut, Lebanon]]).{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} ===World Games=== {{further|Finswimming at the World Games}} Finswimming has featured at the [[World Games]] as a [[World Games sports|trend sport]] since the [[World Games 1981|inaugural games]] held during 1981. Participation is reserved for the best swimmers from the CMAS World Ranking and the best relay teams as selected by the CMAS Finswimming Commission.{{cite web|title=World Games, Kolendra rules fin swimming|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=q0tPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=CY8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2188,1918930&dq=world-games+santa-clara&hl=en|publisher=Ellensburg Daily Record, Washington USA|accessdate=12 August 2013|pages=8|date=July 28, 1981}}{{cite book|title=FINSWIMMING - CMAS RULES VERSION 2012/03 In force as from January 1, 2013 (BoD179 - 22/11/2012)|year=2012|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|location=Rome|page=10|url=http://www.cmas.org/document?sessionId=&fileId=2538&language=1}} ===Other multi-sport events=== Finswimming has appeared at [[multi-sport events]] such as the following: [[Asian Indoor Games]],{{cite web|title=Results: Finswimming (25m)|url=http://maigoc2007.sports.sina.com.cn/php/item_result.php?lan=en&s=7|publisher=Macao 2nd Asian Indoor Games Organising Committee|accessdate=2 December 2013}} [[Bolivarian Games]],{{cite web|title=Underwater medal count|url=http://www.bolivarianos2013.pe/Medalls/ViewMedalTableBySport.aspx?dep=70|publisher=2013 Bolivarian Games|accessdate=2 December 2013|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923223942/http://www.bolivarianos2013.pe/Medalls/ViewMedalTableBySport.aspx?dep=70|archivedate=23 September 2015}} [[Southeast Asian Games]],{{cite web|title=Finswimming results for the 26th SEA Games in Indonesia|url=http://www.cmasasia.org/news/2011/word/26th_SEA_GAMES_INDONESIA_2011.pdf|publisher=Asian Underwater Federation|accessdate=24 October 2013}} World Corporate Games from 1998 to 1992,{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} and the [[World Scholar-Athlete Games]].{{cite web|title=Results, Rankings, and Records, World Scholar-Athlete Games (Finswimming Competition) 7/1/2006-7/1/2006 Kingston, Rhode Island USA|url=http://www.swimmingworldmagazine.com/results/published/3872.asp|publisher=Sports Publications International|accessdate=3 December 2013}} The sport was also demonstrated at the [[2013 Summer Universiade|27th Summer Universiade]] in July 2013 and at the [[2015 European Games]] in June 2015.{{cite web|title=Taking part in the Universiade, Finswimming entered a new era|url=http://www.cmas.org/news/taking-part-in-the-universiade-finswimming-entered-a-new-era|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|accessdate=12 August 2013}}{{cite web|title=First European Games - Baku 2015|url=http://www.cmas.org/news/first-european-games-baku-2015|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|accessdate=22 July 2015}} ===Olympic Games=== As of 2011, no finswimming competition or demonstration has been held at an [[Olympic Games]].{{cite book|last=Mallon|first=Bill|title=Historical dictionary of the Olympic movement|year=2011|publisher=Scarecrow Press|location=Plymouth (UK)|isbn= 9780810875227|page=362|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9mM0XzW03AcC&pg=PA362&lpg=PA362&dq=OLympics+demonstration+finswimming#v=onepage&q=OLympics%20demonstration%20finswimming&f=false|edition=4th|author2=Heijmans, Jeroen }} CMAS which is recognised by the IOC as the international sports federation for underwater sports was so recognised in 1986 solely on the basis of finswimming.{{cite web|title=Recognised Sport Federations, Underwater sports|url=http://www.olympic.org/content/the-ioc/recognised-sport-federations/federation9/|publisher=International Olympic Committee|accessdate=26 July 2014|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819061355/http://www.olympic.org/content/the-ioc/recognised-sport-federations/federation9/|archivedate=19 August 2014}}{{cite web|title=History of Underwater Sports, Finswimming|url=http://history.cmas.org/finswimming|publisher=Confédération Mondiale des Activités Subaquatiques|accessdate=26 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161215163844/http://history.cmas.org/finswimming|archive-date=15 December 2016|url-status=dead}} In 1999, finswimming was reported as being considered for inclusion in the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] in [[Athens]], [[Greece]].{{cite journal|title=Finswimming in 2004 Games?|journal=Swimming World & Junior Swimmer|date=March 1999|volume=40|issue=3|page=13|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/1762160/finswimming-2004-games|accessdate=26 July 2014}} In 2002, the IOC considered underwater sports which includes finswimming as one of the sports to be added to the programme of the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in [[Beijing]], [[China]], but decided to decline admission to it and eight other sports on the basis of:{{cite book|last=Carraroc|first=Franco|title=REVIEW OF THE OLYMPIC PROGRAMME AND THE RECOMMENDATIONS ON THE PROGRAMME OF THE GAMES OF THE XXIX OLYMPIAD, BEIJING 2008 - REPORT BY THE COMMISSION CHAIRMAN|year=2002|publisher=International Olympic Committee|pages=16–17|url=http://www.olympic.org/Documents/Reports/EN/en_report_527.pdf}}
Statistics reviewed on federation affiliation, nations competing in major events and broadcast and press coverage of major events for most requested sports did not indicate a higher level of global participation and interest than sports currently in the Programme, and therefore could not be considered to bring additional value.

country=== * {{annotated link|Finswimming in Australia}} * {{annotated link|Finswimming in the United Kingdom}} * {{annotated link|Finswimming in the United States}} ===Competitors and organisations=== * {{annotated link|Joel Armas}} * {{annotated link|Valentina Artemyeva}} * {{annotated link|Peppo Biscarini}} * {{annotated link|Misty Hyman}} * {{annotated link|Shavarsh Karapetyan}} * {{annotated link|Flori Lang}} * {{annotated link|Vitalina Simonova}} * {{annotated link|Texas Finswimming Association}} ===Records=== * {{annotated link|List of European records in finswimming}} * on the History of CMAS website] *[http://www.cmasworldcup.org/ CMAS World Cup home page]
